req_description: The application shall decode or unescape input into a canonical form only once. This decoding must only occur when encoded data in that form is expected and must be completed before any further processing, such as validation or sanitization.
The application must perform output encoding and escaping either as a final step before being used by its intended interpreter or by the interpreter itself.

Output encoding for HTTP responses, HTML, or XML documents must be context-aware. The system shall encode characters relevant to the specific context (e.g., HTML elements, attributes, CSS) to prevent altering the message or document structure.

When dynamically building URLs, the application shall encode untrusted data according to its context (e.g., URL encoding for query parameters). Only safe URL protocols (e.g., http:, https:) shall be permitted; unsafe protocols like javascript: or data: must be disallowed.
The application must use output encoding or escaping when dynamically building JavaScript content (including JSON) to prevent injection attacks that could alter the message or document structure.
All database queries (SQL, HQL, NoSQL, etc.) must use parameterized queries, ORMs, or entity frameworks to protect against injection attacks. This requirement also applies to stored procedures.
The application must protect against OS command injection by using parameterized OS queries or contextual command line output encoding for all operating system calls.
The application must implement specific security controls to protect against LDAP injection vulnerabilities.
To protect against XPath injection, the application shall use query parameterization or precompiled queries.
LaTeX processors must be configured securely, avoiding insecure flags like --shell-escape. An allowlist of commands shall be used to prevent LaTeX injection attacks.
The application shall escape special characters within regular expressions to prevent them from being misinterpreted as metacharacters.

The application must protect against CSV and Formula Injection. When exporting CSV content, it shall follow the escaping rules of RFC 4180. For all spreadsheet formats, field values starting with special characters (=, +, -, @, \t, \0) must be escaped with a single quote.
All untrusted HTML input from sources like WYSIWYG editors must be sanitized using an approved and secure HTML sanitization library or framework feature.
The application must avoid using eval() and other dynamic code execution features (e.g., SpEL). If unavoidable, any included user input must be sanitized before execution.
Data passed to a potentially dangerous context must be sanitized beforehand by enforcing safety measures, such as allowlisting safe characters and trimming oversized input.
User-supplied SVG content must be validated or sanitized to ensure it only contains application-safe tags and attributes and is free of executable content like scripts or foreignObject.
The application must sanitize or disable user-supplied scriptable or expression-based content, such as Markdown, CSS, or XSL stylesheets.

To protect against SSRF, the application must validate untrusted data used in outbound requests against a strict allowlist of protocols, domains, paths, and ports, and sanitize any potentially dangerous characters.

The application must prevent template injection by disallowing the creation of templates from untrusted input. If unavoidable, any untrusted input used in dynamic template creation must be sanitized or strictly validated.
The application shall sanitize untrusted input before use in JNDI queries, and JNDI must be securely configured to prevent injection attacks.
The application must sanitize content before sending it to memcache to prevent injection attacks.
Potentially malicious format strings must be sanitized before being processed to avoid unexpected behavior.
The application shall sanitize user input before passing it to mail systems to protect against SMTP or IMAP injection.

Regular expressions must be designed to be free of elements that cause exponential backtracking. Additionally, untrusted input must be sanitized before being processed by regular expressions to mitigate Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks.
The application must use memory-safe string functions, safer memory copy operations, and secure pointer arithmetic to prevent stack, buffer, and heap overflows.
The application shall use sign, range, and input validation techniques to prevent integer overflows.

Dynamically allocated memory and resources must be properly released after use. Any references or pointers to freed memory must be removed or set to null to prevent dangling pointers and use-after-free vulnerabilities.
XML parsers must be configured restrictively, with unsafe features like external entity resolution disabled, to prevent XML eXternal Entity (XXE) attacks.

When deserializing untrusted data, the application must enforce safe input handling, such as using an allowlist of permitted object types. Insecure deserialization mechanisms must not be used with untrusted input.

All parsers used for the same data type (e.g., JSON, XML) must perform parsing consistently and use the same character encoding to prevent interoperability vulnerabilities that could lead to RFI or SSRF attacks.
The application's documentation shall define clear input validation rules for checking data items against their expected structure (e.g., email addresses, internal data formats).
The application's documentation shall define rules for validating the logical and contextual consistency of combined data items (e.g., ensuring a city matches a postal code).
The application's documentation must define all business logic limits and validations, including both per-user and global thresholds.

All application input must be validated to enforce business and functional expectations. This validation shall use a positive security model (allowlisting) based on expected values, patterns, ranges, or structures.
All input validation must be enforced on a trusted, server-side layer. Client-side validation shall be considered a usability feature only and not a security control.
The application must ensure that combinations of related data items are valid and reasonable according to predefined business rules.
The application must enforce that business logic flows are processed in the expected sequential order for a user, preventing any steps from being skipped.
Business logic limits, as defined in the documentation, must be implemented to prevent exploitation.
Business logic operations must be transactional, ensuring that they either complete successfully in their entirety or are fully rolled back to their previous state upon failure.
The application must use business-level locking mechanisms to prevent double-booking or overselling of limited-quantity resources.
High-value business logic flows (e.g., large transfers, contract approvals) shall require multi-user approval to prevent unauthorized or accidental actions.

The application must implement anti-automation controls (e.g., rate limiting, CAPTCHA) to protect against excessive calls that could lead to denial-of-service, data exfiltration, or resource exhaustion.
Critical business logic flows must require realistic human interaction timing to prevent excessively rapid, automated submissions.
The application documentation shall state the expected browser security features (e.g., HTTPS, HSTS, CSP) and define application behavior if these are unavailable.

The application shall implement security controls (e.g., checking Sec-Fetch-* headers, CSP sandbox, Content-Disposition: attachment) to prevent browsers from rendering content or functionality in an incorrect context.
Content intended for display as text shall be handled using safe rendering functions (e.g., createTextNode, textContent) to prevent unintended execution of HTML or JavaScript.

The application shall employ explicit variable declarations, strict type checking, avoid global variables on the document object, and use namespace isolation to prevent DOM clobbering in client-side JavaScript.
Cookies shall have the 'Secure' attribute set. If the '\__Host-' prefix is not used, the '__Secure-' prefix must be used for the cookie name.
Each cookie's 'SameSite' attribute shall be set according to its purpose to limit exposure to UI redress and CSRF attacks.
Cookies shall have the '__Host-' prefix unless explicitly designed for sharing with other hosts.
Cookies whose values should not be accessible to client-side scripts (e.g., session tokens) must have the 'HttpOnly' attribute set, and the value must only be transferred via the 'Set-Cookie' header.
The combined length of a cookie's name and value shall not exceed 4096 bytes when written by the application.
All responses shall include a Strict-Transport-Security header to enforce an HSTS policy with a max-age of at least 1 year. The policy must include subdomains.

The Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Access-Control-Allow-Origin header shall either be a fixed value or validated against an allowlist if using the Origin request header. Responses using 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *' must not include sensitive information.

HTTP responses shall include a Content-Security-Policy (CSP) header with directives (including object-src 'none' and base-uri 'none') using a per-response policy with nonces or hashes to restrict content execution.
All HTTP responses shall contain an 'X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff' header.
The application shall set a Referrer-Policy (via header or HTML attributes) to prevent leakage of sensitive data (e.g., URL paths, query strings) via the 'Referer' header.
Every HTTP response shall use the Content-Security-Policy 'frame-ancestors' directive to control embedding and prevent clickjacking.
The Content-Security-Policy header shall specify a location to report violations.
All HTTP responses rendering a document shall include the Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy header with 'same-origin' or 'same-origin-allow-popups' directive.
If not relying on CORS preflight, requests to sensitive functionality must be validated using anti-forgery tokens or non-CORS-safelisted headers to prevent CSRF.

If relying on CORS preflight, the application must ensure sensitive functionality cannot be called with requests that bypass preflight (e.g., by checking Origin/Content-Type or requiring non-safelisted headers).
HTTP requests to sensitive functionality shall use appropriate methods (POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE) and not "safe" methods (GET, HEAD, OPTIONS), or shall use strict validation of Sec-Fetch-* headers.
Separate applications shall be hosted on different hostnames to leverage same-origin policy restrictions.
Messages received via the postMessage interface shall be discarded if the message origin is not trusted or the syntax is invalid.
JSONP functionality must not be enabled anywhere in the application.
Script resource responses (e.g., JavaScript files) must not include data requiring authorization.
Authenticated resources shall only be loaded or embedded when intended, enforced either by strict Sec-Fetch-* header validation or a restrictive Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header.

Client-side assets (JS, CSS, fonts) hosted externally (e.g., on a CDN) must be static, versioned, and validated using Subresource Integrity (SRI), unless a documented security decision justifies otherwise.
The application shall only use client-side technologies that are still supported and considered secure (e.g., no Flash, ActiveX, Java applets).
The application shall only automatically redirect users to external hostnames or domains if the destination is on an allowlist.
The application shall show a notification with a cancellation option when redirecting users to URLs outside its control.
The application's top-level domain shall be added to the HSTS public preload list.
The application shall behave as documented (e.g., warn user, block access) if the browser does not support expected security features.
Every HTTP response with a message body shall contain a Content-Type header matching the content and specifying a safe character encoding (e.g., UTF-8).
Only user-facing endpoints shall automatically redirect from HTTP to HTTPS; other services or endpoints must not implement transparent redirects.
HTTP header fields set by intermediary layers (e.g., X-Forwarded-For) must not be overrideable by the end-user.
The application or API shall block unused HTTP methods and only allow explicitly supported methods (including OPTIONS for preflight).
Highly sensitive requests or transactions traversing multiple systems shall use per-message digital signatures in addition to transport protection.

All application components shall determine HTTP message boundaries correctly according to the HTTP version to prevent request smuggling (respecting Transfer-Encoding over Content-Length in HTTP/1.x, ensuring Content-Length consistency with DATA frames in HTTP/2 & 3).
When generating HTTP messages, the application shall ensure the Content-Length header does not conflict with the content length determined by protocol framing.
The application shall not send nor accept HTTP/2 or HTTP/3 messages containing connection-specific headers (e.g., Transfer-Encoding).
The application shall only accept HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 requests where headers and values contain no CR, LF, or CRLF sequences.
The application shall use validation or sanitization to avoid creating URIs or HTTP request headers that are too long for receiving components.
GraphQL endpoints shall use query allowlisting, depth limiting, amount limiting, or query cost analysis to prevent DoS attacks from expensive queries.
GraphQL introspection queries shall be disabled in production unless the API is intended for public consumption.
All WebSocket connections shall use WebSocket over TLS (WSS).
During the initial HTTP WebSocket handshake, the Origin header shall be checked against an allowlist of allowed origins.
If standard session management cannot be used for WebSockets, dedicated tokens compliant with session management requirements shall be used.
Dedicated WebSocket session tokens shall be initially obtained or validated via the previously authenticated HTTPS session when upgrading.
The documentation shall define permitted file types, extensions, maximum size (including unpacked), download safety measures, and behavior upon detecting malicious files for each upload feature.
The application shall only accept files of a size that can be processed without causing performance loss or DoS.

The application shall check if uploaded file extensions match an allowlist and validate that the file contents correspond to the extension type (e.g., via magic bytes, image rewriting) for all files being accepted.
The application shall check compressed files against maximum allowed uncompressed size and maximum file count before decompression.
A file size quota and maximum file count per user shall be enforced to prevent storage exhaustion.
The application shall not allow uploading compressed files containing symlinks unless specifically required and restricted by an allowlist.
The application shall reject uploaded images with pixel dimensions larger than the maximum allowed to prevent pixel flood attacks.
Files uploaded or generated from untrusted input and stored in public folders must not be executable as server-side code when accessed directly via HTTP.

When creating file paths for file operations, the application shall use internally generated or trusted data, or apply strict validation and sanitization if user-submitted filenames/metadata must be used, to prevent path traversal, LFI/RFI, and SSRF.
Server-side file processing (e.g., decompression) shall ignore user-provided path information to prevent vulnerabilities like zip slip.
The application shall validate or ignore user-submitted filenames (including in parameters) and specify a filename in the Content-Disposition header for downloads.
Filenames served (e.g., in headers or attachments) shall be encoded or sanitized (e.g., per RFC 6266) to preserve document structure and prevent injection.
Files obtained from untrusted sources shall be scanned by antivirus scanners before being served.
Files that may contain executable content (e.g., HTML, PDF, Office documents) must be served with a Content-Disposition: attachment header to prevent unintended execution in the browser.

Application documentation shall define how controls (rate limiting, anti-automation, adaptive response) defend against credential stuffing and brute force, including configuration and prevention of malicious lockout.
A documented list of context-specific words (e.g., organization names, product names) shall be maintained to prevent their use in passwords.
If multiple authentication pathways exist, they shall all be documented along with consistently enforced security controls and authentication strength.
User-set passwords shall be at least 8 characters long (15+ recommended).
Users shall be able to change their password.
Password change functionality shall require the user's current and new password.
Passwords submitted during registration or change shall be checked against a list of at least the top 3000 common passwords matching the application's policy.
Passwords of any composition shall be allowed, without rules limiting character types (no minimum upper/lower/number/special character requirements).
Password input fields shall use `type="password"`. Temporary viewing of the password or last character typed may be allowed.
Paste functionality, browser password helpers, and external password managers shall be permitted in password fields.
The application shall verify the user's password exactly as received, without modifications like truncation or case transformation.
Passwords of at least 64 characters shall be permitted.
A user's password shall remain valid until compromised or rotated by the user; periodic credential rotation must not be required.
The documented list of context-specific words shall be used to prevent easily guessable passwords.
Passwords submitted during registration or change shall be checked against a set of breached passwords.
Controls against credential stuffing and brute force shall be implemented as defined in the documentation.
Default user accounts (e.g., "root", "admin") must not be present or must be disabled.
Multi-factor authentication must be used for application access, with one factor being a hardware-based, phishing-resistant mechanism requiring user interaction (e.g., FIDO key).
If multiple authentication pathways exist, there shall be no undocumented pathways, and security controls/strength must be enforced consistently.
Users shall be notified of suspicious authentication attempts (successful or unsuccessful, e.g., unusual location, multiple failures followed by success).
Email must not be used as either a single-factor or multi-factor authentication mechanism.
Users shall be notified after updates to their authentication details (e.g., credential resets, email/username changes).
Failed authentication challenges (including registration/forgot password) must not allow deduction of valid users (e.g., via error messages, timing).
System-generated initial passwords or activation codes shall be securely random, follow the password policy, expire quickly or after first use, and must not become the long-term password.
Password hints and knowledge-based authentication ("secret questions") must not be present.
A secure password reset process shall be implemented that does not bypass enabled MFA mechanisms.
If an MFA factor is lost, identity proofing shall be performed at the same level as during enrollment.
Renewal instructions for expiring authentication mechanisms shall be sent with sufficient time, including automated reminders if necessary.
Administrative-initiated password resets must not allow the administrator to choose or know the user's new password.
Lookup secrets, out-of-band codes/requests, and TOTPs shall be usable only once.
Lookup secrets with < 112 bits entropy stored server-side shall be hashed with an approved password hashing algorithm using a 32-bit random salt; secrets >= 112 bits may use a standard hash.
Lookup secrets, out-of-band codes, and TOTP seeds shall be generated using a CSPRNG.
Lookup secrets and out-of-band codes shall have a minimum entropy of 20 bits.
Out-of-band requests/codes/tokens and TOTPs shall have defined lifetimes (max 10 mins for OOB, max 30 secs for TOTP).
All authentication factors (including physical devices) must be revocable.
Biometric authentication shall only be used as a secondary factor alongside something the user has or knows.
TOTP checks shall use a trusted time source, not client-provided time.
PSTN-based OTPs (phone/SMS) must not be available as authentication options.
Out-of-band authentication requests/codes/tokens shall be bound to the original authentication request and usable only for that request.
Code-based out-of-band mechanisms shall be protected against brute force by rate limiting; consider codes with >= 64 bits entropy.
Where push notifications are used for MFA, rate limiting shall be used to prevent push bombing attacks; number matching may also be used.
Certificates used to verify cryptographic authentication assertions must be stored securely to prevent modification.
Challenge nonces for cryptographic authentication shall be at least 64 bits long and statistically unique or unique over the device's lifetime.
If supporting multiple IdPs, the application must prevent identity spoofing (e.g., by namespacing user IDs with the IdP ID).
The presence and integrity of digital signatures on authentication assertions (JWTs, SAML) must always be validated; unsigned or invalid assertions shall be rejected.
SAML assertions shall be processed uniquely and used only once within their validity period.

If specific authentication strength/methods/recentness are required for certain functions, the application must verify this using information from the IdP (e.g., OIDC claims 'acr', 'amr', 'auth_time'); if unavailable, assume minimum strength.
User session inactivity timeout and absolute maximum session lifetime shall be documented, justified, and appropriate.
Documentation shall define the allowed number of concurrent sessions per account and the behavior when the limit is reached.
All systems managing sessions in a federated identity ecosystem (e.g., SSO) shall be documented, including controls for coordinating session lifetimes and termination.
The application shall perform all session token verification using a trusted, backend service.
The application shall use either self-contained or reference tokens that are dynamically generated for session management, not static API secrets and keys.
Reference tokens used to represent user sessions shall be unique, generated using a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator (CSPRNG), and possess at least 128 bits of entropy.
The application shall generate a new session token on user authentication (including re-authentication) and terminate the current session token.
An inactivity timeout shall enforce re-authentication based on documented risk analysis.
An absolute maximum session lifetime shall enforce re-authentication based on documented risk analysis.

When session termination is triggered (e.g., logout, expiration), the application shall disallow any further use of the session (e.g., invalidate server-side data for reference tokens, use revocation lists for self-contained tokens).
The application shall terminate all active sessions when a user account is disabled or deleted.
After a change/removal of an authentication factor, the application shall offer the user the option to terminate all other active sessions.
All authenticated pages shall provide easy and visible access to logout functionality.
Application administrators shall be able to terminate active sessions for individual users or all users.
The application shall require full re-authentication before allowing modifications to sensitive account attributes affecting authentication (e.g., email, phone, MFA settings).
Users shall be able to view and (after re-authenticating with at least one factor) terminate any or all of their currently active sessions.
The application shall require further authentication (at least one factor or secondary verification) before performing highly sensitive transactions.

Session lifetime and termination between Relying Parties and Identity Providers shall behave as documented, enforcing re-authentication when necessary (e.g., max time between IdP authentications reached).
Session creation shall require user consent or an explicit action, preventing silent session creation.
Authorization documentation shall define rules for restricting function-level and data-specific access based on consumer permissions and resource attributes.
Authorization documentation shall define rules for field-level access restrictions (read/write) based on permissions and attributes, potentially depending on object state.
Application documentation shall define the environmental and contextual attributes (e.g., time, location, IP, device) used for security decisions (authN/authZ).

Authentication and authorization documentation shall define how environmental/contextual factors are used in decision-making, including attributes evaluated, risk thresholds, and actions taken (allow, challenge, deny, step-up).
The application shall ensure function-level access is restricted to consumers with explicit permissions.
The application shall ensure data-specific access is restricted to consumers with explicit permissions for specific data items (preventing IDOR/BOLA).
The application shall ensure field-level access is restricted to consumers with explicit permissions for specific fields (preventing BOPLA).
Adaptive security controls based on consumer environmental/contextual attributes shall be implemented for authN/authZ decisions (at session start and during the session) as defined in documentation.
The application shall enforce authorization rules at a trusted service layer, not relying on client-side controls.
Changes to values used for authorization decisions shall be applied immediately. If not possible (e.g., self-contained tokens), mitigating controls (alerting, reverting) must be in place.
Access to an object shall be based on the originating subject's permissions, not an intermediary service acting on their behalf (e.g., use the user's token for chained service calls).
Multi-tenant applications shall use cross-tenant controls to ensure consumer operations cannot affect unauthorized tenants.

Access to administrative interfaces shall incorporate multiple security layers (continuous identity verification, device posture, contextual risk), not relying solely on network location or trusted endpoints.
Self-contained tokens shall be validated using their digital signature or MAC before acceptance.
Only algorithms on an allowlist shall be used to create/verify tokens for a given context (no 'None' algorithm; prevent key confusion if both symmetric/asymmetric are needed).
Key material used to validate tokens must come from trusted, pre-configured sources for the issuer; headers specifying keys/sources (e.g., jku, x5u, jwk) must be validated against an allowlist.
If a validity time span is present (e.g., JWT 'nbf', 'exp'), the token shall only be accepted if verification time is within this span.
The receiving service shall validate the token type and intended purpose before acceptance (e.g., only access tokens for authorization, ID tokens for authentication proof).
The service shall only accept tokens intended for use with that service (audience validation, e.g., JWT 'aud' claim).

If an issuer uses the same private key for different audiences, issued tokens must contain an audience restriction uniquely identifying intended audiences; dynamically provisioned audiences must be validated to prevent impersonation.
Tokens shall only be sent to components that strictly need them (e.g., in BFF pattern, backend holds tokens, not frontend).

The client shall only accept values from the authorization server (auth code, ID Token) if they result from a flow initiated by the same user agent session/transaction, verified using unguessable, transaction-specific secrets bound to the client and session (e.g., PKCE code_verifier, state, OIDC nonce).
If using the code flow, the OAuth client shall protect against CSRF token request triggers using PKCE or by checking the 'state' parameter.
If interacting with multiple authorization servers, the OAuth client shall defend against mix-up attacks (e.g., by requiring and validating the 'iss' parameter in responses).
The OAuth client shall only request the required scopes (or other authorization parameters).
The resource server shall only accept access tokens intended for that service (audience validation via token content or introspection).
The resource server shall enforce authorization based on delegated authorization claims from the access token (e.g., 'sub', 'scope', 'authorization_details').
When identifying a user from an access token for access control, the resource server must use claims that cannot be reassigned (typically 'iss' + 'sub').
If specific authentication strength/methods/recentness are required, the resource server shall verify the access token satisfies these constraints (e.g., via OIDC 'acr', 'amr', 'auth_time').
The resource server shall require sender-constrained access tokens (mTLS or DPoP) to prevent use/replay of stolen tokens.
The authorization server shall validate redirect URIs based on a client-specific allowlist of pre-registered URIs using exact string comparison.
Authorization codes shall be usable only once; subsequent attempts must be rejected and related tokens revoked.
Authorization codes shall be short-lived (maximum lifetime up to 1 minute).
For a given client, the authorization server shall only allow necessary grant types (Implicit 'token' and ROPC 'password' grants must not be used).
The authorization server shall mitigate refresh token replay attacks for public clients using sender-constraints (DPoP or mTLS).
If using the code grant, the authorization server shall require PKCE (requiring valid 'code_challenge' != 'plain' in auth request, validating 'code_verifier' in token request).

If supporting unauthenticated dynamic client registration, the authorization server must mitigate risks by validating client metadata (URIs), ensuring user consent, and warning users about untrusted clients.
Refresh tokens shall have an absolute expiration, even if sliding expiration is used.
Refresh tokens and reference access tokens must be revocable by an authorized user via the authorization server UI.
Confidential clients must be authenticated for backchannel requests (token, PAR, revocation).
The authorization server configuration shall only assign required scopes to the OAuth client.
For a given client, the authorization server shall only allow needed 'response_mode' values (enforced via validation, PAR, or JAR).
The 'code' grant type shall always be used with Pushed Authorization Requests (PAR).
The authorization server shall issue only sender-constrained access tokens (mTLS or DPoP bound).
For server-side clients, the authorization server shall ensure the 'authorization_details' parameter originates from the client backend without user tampering (e.g., using PAR or JAR).
The client must be confidential, and the authorization server shall require strong, replay-resistant client authentication methods (mTLS or private key JWT).
The OIDC client (relying party) shall mitigate ID Token replay (e.g., matching 'nonce' claim to value sent in auth request).
The client shall uniquely identify the user from ID Token claims that cannot be reassigned within the IdP (usually 'sub').
The client shall reject authorization server metadata if the issuer URL does not exactly match the pre-configured expected issuer URL.
The client shall validate the ID Token audience by checking that the 'aud' claim equals the client's 'client_id'.
When using OIDC back-channel logout, the relying party must mitigate DoS and JWT confusion by verifying the logout token type ('logout+jwt'), presence of 'event' claim, and absence of 'nonce' claim.
The OpenID Provider shall only allow response modes 'code', 'ciba', 'id_token', or 'id_token code' ('token'/Implicit flow must not be used).
The OpenID Provider shall mitigate DoS through forced logout (e.g., via user confirmation or validating 'id_token_hint').
The authorization server shall ensure user consent for each authorization request; explicit consent must be prompted if client identity cannot be assured.
User consent prompts shall clearly present information about the requested authorizations (scopes, resources, RAR details), client identity, and authorization lifetime.
Users shall be able to review, modify, and revoke consents granted through the authorization server.
A documented policy for cryptographic key management and lifecycle (following standards like NIST SP 800-57) shall exist, including preventing key oversharing.
A cryptographic inventory (keys, algorithms, certs) shall be maintained and regularly updated, documenting usage restrictions.
Cryptographic discovery mechanisms shall be used to identify all crypto instances in the system.
The cryptographic inventory shall include a documented migration plan for future standards like post-quantum cryptography.
Industry-validated implementations (libraries, hardware-accelerated) shall be used for crypto operations.
The application shall be designed with crypto agility, allowing algorithms, key lengths, modes, etc., to be reconfigured or swapped to protect against breaks and enable future upgrades (e.g., PQC).
All cryptographic primitives shall utilize a minimum of 128 bits of security (considering algorithm, key size, configuration).
All cryptographic operations shall be constant-time to avoid timing side-channel leaks.
All cryptographic modules shall fail securely, handling errors to prevent vulnerabilities like Padding Oracles.
Insecure block modes (e.g., ECB) and weak padding schemes (e.g., PKCS#1 v1.5) must not be used.
Only approved ciphers and modes (e.g., AES with GCM) shall be used.
Encrypted data must be protected against unauthorized modification, preferably using authenticated encryption or encrypt-then-MAC.
Nonces, IVs, and other single-use numbers must not be reused for the same key; generation method must suit the algorithm.
Any combined encryption and MAC scheme shall operate in encrypt-then-MAC mode.
Only approved hash functions shall be used for cryptographic purposes (signatures, HMAC, KDF, RNG); disallowed functions (e.g., MD5) must not be used.
Passwords shall be stored using an approved, computationally intensive KDF (password hashing function) with currently recommended parameters.
Hash functions used for digital signatures, data authentication, or integrity must be collision-resistant (>=256 bits output if needed) or second pre-image resistant (>=128 bits output if needed).
Approved key derivation functions with key stretching parameters shall be used when deriving secret keys from passwords, configured to balance security and performance.
All non-guessable random numbers/strings shall be generated using a CSPRNG and have at least 128 bits of entropy (Note: UUIDs do not meet this).
The random number generation mechanism shall be designed to work securely under heavy demand.
Only approved algorithms/modes shall be used for public key generation/seeding and digital signature generation/verification; key generation must not produce insecure keys.
Approved algorithms with secure parameters shall be used for key exchange (e.g., Diffie-Hellman) to prevent MitM or breaks.
Full memory encryption shall be used to protect sensitive data while in use.
Data minimization shall ensure minimal data exposure during processing; data must be encrypted immediately after use or as soon as feasible.
Only the latest recommended TLS versions (e.g., TLS 1.2, TLS 1.3) shall be enabled, with the latest version preferred.
Only recommended cipher suites which provide forward secrecy shall be enabled, with the strongest cipher suites preferred.
The application shall validate that mTLS client certificates are trusted before using the identity for authN/authZ.
Proper certificate revocation checking (e.g., OCSP Stapling) shall be enabled and configured.
Encrypted Client Hello (ECH) shall be enabled in TLS settings to protect metadata like SNI.

section_name: HTTPS Communication with External Facing Services
req_description: TLS shall be used for all client connectivity to external facing HTTP-based services, without fallback to insecure communication.

section_name: HTTPS Communication with External Facing Services
req_description: External facing services shall use publicly trusted TLS certificates.

section_name: General Service to Service Communication Security
req_description: An encrypted protocol (e.g., TLS) shall be used for all application inbound/outbound connections (monitoring, management, middleware, DBs, APIs, etc.), without fallback to insecure protocols.

section_name: General Service to Service Communication Security
req_description: TLS clients shall validate certificates received before communicating with a TLS server.

section_name: General Service to Service Communication Security
req_description: TLS or another appropriate transport encryption shall be used for all internal HTTP-based service communication, without fallback to insecure protocols.

section_name: General Service to Service Communication Security
req_description: TLS connections between internal services shall use trusted certificates (internal CAs or specific self-signed certs must be explicitly trusted by consumers).

section_name: General Service to Service Communication Security
req_description: Internal service-to-service communication shall use strong, replay-resistant authentication (e.g., mTLS) to verify endpoints.
All communication needs (including external dependencies and user-providable destinations) shall be documented.
Documentation for each external service shall define max concurrent connections and behavior upon reaching the limit.
Application documentation shall define resource management strategies (release, timeout, failure handling, retry logic) for all external systems/services.
Application documentation shall define critical secrets and their rotation schedule.
Backend component communication not using standard user sessions shall be authenticated using service accounts, short-term tokens, or certificates (not static credentials like passwords/API keys).
Backend component communication shall use accounts with least privilege.
Credentials used for service authentication must not be default credentials.
An allowlist shall define the external resources/systems the application is permitted to communicate with (enforced at app, web server, or firewall layer).
The web/application server shall be configured with an allowlist of resources/systems it can send requests to or load data/files from.
Application connections to separate services shall follow documented configurations (max connections, timeouts, retries).

A secrets management solution using a hardware-backed module (HSM) shall be used to securely manage backend secrets (passwords, keys, API keys, etc.); secrets must not be in source code or build artifacts.
Access to secrets shall adhere to the principle of least privilege.
All cryptographic operations shall use an isolated security module (vault, HSM) to protect key material.
Secrets shall expire and be rotated based on application documentation.
The application shall be deployed without source control metadata (.git, .svn) or ensure these folders are inaccessible.
Debug modes must be disabled for all components in production.
Web servers must not expose directory listings unless explicitly intended.
The HTTP TRACE method must not be supported in production.
Documentation (e.g., internal API docs) and monitoring endpoints must not be exposed unless explicitly intended.
The application must not expose detailed version information of backend components.
The web tier shall be configured to serve only files with specific allowed extensions.
All sensitive data created and processed by the application shall be identified and classified into protection levels, considering regulatory requirements.
Each sensitive data protection level shall have documented protection requirements (encryption, integrity, retention, logging, access control, privacy tech, etc.).
Sensitive data shall only be sent server-side in the HTTP message body or headers, not in the URL or query string.
The application shall prevent sensitive data caching in server components or ensure secure purging after use.
Defined sensitive data shall not be sent to untrusted parties (e.g., user trackers).
Controls for sensitive data (encryption, integrity, retention, logging, access, privacy tech) shall be implemented per the documented protection level.
Caching mechanisms shall only cache responses with expected content types, without sensitive dynamic content, and return 404/302 for non-existent files to prevent Web Cache Deception.
The application shall return only the minimum required sensitive data; complete data, if needed, should be masked in the UI unless explicitly viewed.
Sensitive information shall be subject to data retention classification, ensuring deletion on a defined schedule or as needed.
Sensitive information shall be removed from the metadata of user-submitted files unless consented to by the user.
Authenticated data shall be cleared from client storage (e.g., DOM) after session termination ('Clear-Site-Data' header may help).
The application shall set sufficient anti-caching HTTP headers (e.g., Cache-Control: no-store) for sensitive data.
Data stored in browser storage (localStorage, sessionStorage, IndexedDB, cookies) must not contain sensitive data, except for session tokens.
Application documentation shall define risk-based remediation timeframes for vulnerable 3rd party components and general library updates.
An inventory (e.g., SBOM) of all third-party libraries shall be maintained, verifying components come from trusted, maintained repositories.
Application documentation shall identify time/resource-demanding functionality and define defenses against overuse/DoS (e.g., async processing, queues, limits).
Application documentation shall highlight third-party libraries considered "risky components."
Application documentation shall highlight parts using "dangerous functionality."
The application shall only contain components within their documented update/remediation timeframes.
The application shall implement documented defenses against loss of availability due to time/resource-demanding functionality.
The production environment shall only include required functionality, excluding test code, samples, or development features.
Third-party components and their transitive dependencies must be included from expected repositories, mitigating dependency confusion risks.
Additional protections (sandboxing, isolation) shall be implemented around "dangerous functionality" or "risky components" as documented.
The application shall return only the required subset of fields from data objects.
Where the application backend calls external URLs, it shall be configured not to follow redirects unless intended.
The application shall implement countermeasures against mass assignment attacks by limiting allowed fields per action.

Proxying/middleware components shall correctly transfer the original user IP using trusted, non-manipulable fields, and the application/web server shall use this correct value for logging/security decisions.
The application shall explicitly ensure variables are of the correct type and perform strict equality/comparator operations to prevent type juggling/confusion.
JavaScript code shall be written to prevent prototype pollution (e.g., using Set() or Map()).
The application shall have defenses against HTTP parameter pollution, especially if the framework conflates parameter sources.
Shared objects in multi-threaded code must be accessed safely using thread-safe types and synchronization (locks, semaphores) to prevent race conditions.
Checks on resource state (existence, permissions) and dependent actions must be performed atomically to prevent TOCTOU race conditions.
Locks shall be used consistently to avoid deadlocks/livelocks, with locking logic encapsulated within the resource management code.
Resource allocation policies shall prevent thread starvation by ensuring fair access (e.g., using thread pools).
A log inventory shall exist, documenting events logged, formats, storage, usage, access control, and retention for each layer.
Each log entry shall include necessary metadata (when, where, who, what) for detailed investigation.
Time sources for logging shall be synchronized; timestamps shall use UTC or include an explicit time zone offset.
The application shall only store or broadcast logs to documented files and services.
Logs shall be readable and correlatable by the log processor, preferably using a common format.
Sensitive data logging shall be enforced based on the data's protection level (e.g., disallow logging, hash/mask values).
All authentication operations (success/failure) shall be logged, including relevant metadata (auth type, factors).
All authorization decisions shall be logged, including sensitive data access (without logging the sensitive data itself).
The application shall log documented security events and attempts to bypass security controls (validation, business logic, anti-automation).
The application shall log unexpected errors and security control failures (e.g., backend TLS failures).
All logging components shall appropriately encode data to prevent log injection.
Logs shall be protected from unauthorized access and modification.
Logs shall be securely transmitted to a logically separate system for analysis, detection, and alerting.
A generic message shall be returned upon unexpected or security-sensitive errors, exposing no sensitive internal data (stack traces, keys, etc.).
The application shall operate securely when external resource access fails (e.g., using circuit breakers, graceful degradation).
The application shall fail gracefully and securely, preventing fail-open conditions (e.g., processing a transaction despite validation errors).
A "last resort" error handler shall be defined to catch all unhandled exceptions, ensuring errors are logged and do not crash the application process.
The TURN service shall only allow access to non-reserved IP addresses (public IPs).
The TURN service must not be susceptible to resource exhaustion from legitimate users opening many ports.
The DTLS certificate key shall be managed and protected according to the documented key management policy.
The media server shall be configured to use and support approved DTLS cipher suites and a secure DTLS-SRTP protection profile.
SRTP authentication shall be checked at the media server to prevent RTP injection leading to DoS or media insertion.
The media server must continue processing media traffic when encountering malformed SRTP packets.
The media server must continue processing media traffic during a flood of SRTP packets from legitimate users.
The media server must not be susceptible to the DTLS "ClientHello" Race Condition vulnerability.
Any associated media recording mechanisms must continue processing during SRTP floods from legitimate users.
The DTLS certificate shall be checked against the SDP fingerprint attribute, terminating the stream on failure.
The signaling server must continue processing legitimate signaling messages during a flood attack (e.g., via rate limiting).
The signaling server must continue processing legitimate messages when encountering malformed messages that could cause DoS (via input validation, safe error handling, etc.).
